reasoning:
First off, streaming video is outside my circle of competence. I stick to simple businesses — consumer products, railroads, insurance — not the shifting sands of technology and content costs. When I venture where I don’t understand the drivers, I invite risk. 

Second, Netflix shows no durable moat. Its operating margin may look healthy at roughly 38%, but ROE sits at a weak 6.5% and ROIC at 3.7%. Only 0 out of 10 periods had ROE above 15%, so there’s no consistent advantage over newcomers. High churn, intense competition and rising content spend leave margins vulnerable. 

Management has been diluting shareholders with recent stock issuance and pays no dividend, suggesting they can’t generate enough cash to fund growth internally. Owner earnings are negative at roughly $-3.43 per share, and debt to equity is high at 0.8x. Inconsistent earnings growth and a patchy track record raise red flags on financial stability. 

On valuation, a three-stage DCF spits out a negative intrinsic value (roughly −$49 per share after haircut), implying a margin of safety of −103%. In plain English, you’re paying for losses and future uncertainty. 

Compared with owning Coca-Cola or See’s Candies — where pricing power, steady cash flow and management integrity are proven — Netflix simply doesn’t measure up. There’s no margin of safety and too many unknowns over the long haul. I’m steering clear.

fundamental_analysis.details: Weak ROE of 6.5%; High debt to equity ratio of 0.8; Strong operating margins; Current ratio data not available

consistency_analysis.details: Inconsistent earnings growth pattern; Total earnings growth of 77.9% over past 10 periods

moat_analysis.details: Inconsistent ROE: only 0/10 periods >15%; Decent operating margins (avg: 40.1%) suggest some competitive advantage; High performance stability (73.4%) suggests strong competitive moat

book_value_analysis.details: Good book value per share growth pattern

management_analysis.details: Recent common stock issuance (potential dilution); No or minimal dividends paid

details: Using three-stage DCF: Stage 1 (6.8%, 5y), Stage 2 (3.4%, 5y), Terminal (2.5%)
